author: Pyropuncher

text: I meant humor wise only.  The Subs does contain a certain amount of more emotion.  But I found (entirely my own opinion) the Dubs to be hysterical.  And maybe I got a stream with bad subs but they didn't contain the same amount of humor.  Maybe it has to do with interpretation.  The piece might have been intended as more serious in Japan but taken more as a funny work when brought to Europe or the States.

text: I watched both versions. The dub is fantastically well done. Chris Patton is one of the most experienced English VAs to date. However, I feel the subtitled version portrays more emotion. That's not saying either version is bad though. What you said about the subs losing something in translation in my opinion is completely false.
author: Pyropuncher

text: Ah, I love this theme. My other favourite theme is Hitori Bocchi. This series really struck a cord with me. I was living my life exactly like Satou. Possibly the most realistic portrayal of social anxiety Iâ€™ve seen on TV. The show is truly salute to all that live their everyday lives as it is.  Truly, this anime is much closer to us and our lives than we would think. It helped me a lot.
author: Pyropuncher

text: I know there's a lot of outcry from purists about watching Dubbed but this is definitely one you should.  I watched part of the series in Subbed and the rest in Dubbed and there is no comparison.  The Dubbed are absolutely hysterically funny the Subs just lose something in translation.

author: BlackSpeakersOhYeah

text: I've started watching this series, I basically chose the first recommendation I saw, having no idea what it would be about. It's definitely... interesting so far. It's about a university dropout leading a reclusive life in Tokyo. I can definitely see how some people could relate to him though. I wasn't very sold at first but after a couple episodes, it's starting to grow on me and I'm really enjoying it now. Sometimes funny, sometimes sad. Great soundtrack too.
author: SupraDarky
